org.jgrapes.core.internal

Class EventBase<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jgrapes.core.internal.EventBase<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the result type of the event. Use Void if handling the event does not produce a result
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.util.concurrent.Future<T>, Matchable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Event

    public abstract class EventBase<T>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Matchable, java.util.concurrent.Future<T>
    Provides the implementations of methods to class Event that need access to classes or methods that are visible in the implementation package only. The class is not intended to be used as base class for any other class.
    Author:
    Michael N. Lipp

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected Channel[] channels
      The channels that this event is to be fired on if no channels are specified explicitly when firing.

    • Constructor Detail

        public EventBase()

    • Method Detail

      • channels

        public Channel[] channels()
        Returns the channels associated with the event. Before an event has been fired, this returns the channels set with setChannels(Channel[]). After an event has been fired, this returns the channels that the event has effectively been fired on (see Manager.fire(Event, Channel...)).
        Returns:
        the channels

      • channels

        public <C> C[] channels(java.lang.Class<C> type)
        Returns the subset of channels that are assignable to the given type.
        Type Parameters:
        C - the given type's class
        Parameters:
        type - the class to look for
        Returns:
        the filtered channels
        See Also:
        channels()

      • firstChannel

        public <C> C firstChannel(java.lang.Class<C> type)
        Look through the event'channels and return the first (and usually only) channel of given type.
        Type Parameters:
        C - the given type's class
        Parameters:
        type - the class to look for
        Returns:
        the channel or null

      • setChannels

        public Event<T> setChannels(Channel... channels)
        Sets the channels that the event is fired on if no channels are specified explicitly when firing the event (see Manager.fire(Event, Channel...)).
        Parameters:
        channels - the channels to set
        Returns:
        the object for easy chaining
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the method is called after this event has been fired

      • enqueued

        protected boolean enqueued()
        Returns true if the event has been enqueued in a pipeline.
        Returns:
        the result

      • getResult

        protected T getResult()
        Allows access to the intermediate result before the completion of the event.
        Returns:
        the intermediate result

      • tieTo

        public Event<T> tieTo(EventBase<T> other)
        Tie the result of this event to the result of the other event. Changes of either event's results will subsequently be applied to both events.

        This is useful when an event is replaced by another event during handling like: fire((new Event()).tieTo(oldEvent.stop()))

        Parameters:
        other - the event to tie to
        Returns:
        the object for easy chaining

      • handlingError

        protected abstract void handlingError(EventPipeline eventProcessor,
                                      java.lang.Throwable throwable)
        Invoked when an exception occurs while invoking a handler for an event.
        Parameters:
        eventProcessor - the manager that has invoked the handler
        throwable - the exception that has been thrown by the handler

      • stop

        public Event<T> stop()
        Can be called during the execution of an event handler to indicate that the event should not be processed further. All remaining handlers for this event will be skipped.
        Returns:
        the object for easy chaining

      • getCompletedEvents

        public java.util.Set<Event<?>> getCompletedEvents()
        Returns the events to be thrown when this event and all events caused by it have been handled.
        Returns:
        the completed events

      • addCompletedEvent

        public Event<T> addCompletedEvent(Event<?> completedEvent)
        Adds the event to the events to be thrown when this event and all events caused by it have been handled.
        Parameters:
        completedEvent - the completedEvent to add
        Returns:
        the object for easy chaining

      • isDone

        public boolean isDone()
        Check if this event has been completed.
        Specified by:
        isDone in interface java.util.concurrent.Future<T>
        Returns:
        the completed state

      • handled

        protected void handled()
        Invoked after all handlers for the event have been executed. May be overridden by derived classes to cause some immediate effect (instead of e.g. waiting for the completion event). The default implementation does nothing. This method is invoked by the event handler thread and must not block.

      • cancel

        public boolean cancel(boolean mayInterruptIfRunning)
        The cancel semantics of Futures do not apply to events.
        Specified by:
        cancel in interface java.util.concurrent.Future<T>
        Parameters:
        mayInterruptIfRunning - ignored
        Returns:
        always false as event processing cannot be cancelled
        See Also:
        Future.cancel(boolean)

      • isCancelled

        public boolean isCancelled()
        The cancel semantics of Futures do not apply to events.
        Specified by:
        isCancelled in interface java.util.concurrent.Future<T>
        Returns:
        always false as event processing cannot be cancelled
        See Also:
        Future.isCancelled()
